articles.headline: A Filmmaker, a Spy and France’s Richest Man Meet in a Paris Court
articles.snippet: Bernard Arnault, the head of LVMH, squared off with a documentary maker in a case of espionage gone wrong, a showdown that had been brewing for years.
articles.abstract: Bernard Arnault, the head of LVMH, squared off with a documentary maker in a case of espionage gone wrong, a showdown that had been brewing for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: François Ruffin had just started filming a satirical documentary about Bernard Arnault, France’s richest man and head of the LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton luxury conglomerate, when he became suspicious about a volunteer on his staff.

articles.headline: Resist Trump? On Immigration, Top Democrats See Room for Compromise.
articles.snippet: In interviews, a range of Democratic governors expressed some defiance toward the president-elect’s expected crackdown, but also showed a surprising willingness to work with him.
articles.abstract: In interviews, a range of Democratic governors expressed some defiance toward the president-elect’s expected crackdown, but also showed a surprising willingness to work with him.
articles.lead_paragraph: As President-elect Donald J. Trump promises to deport millions of undocumented immigrants, Democratic governors are bracing themselves to be on the front lines of an emotional and politically explosive battle against his administration.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti, Katie Glueck and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: Finance Moguls Revel in Trump’s Return and Ignore the Peril
articles.snippet: The financial world sees plenty of opportunity in the return of President-elect Donald J. Trump. For now, Wall Streeters are looking past the risks.
articles.abstract: The financial world sees plenty of opportunity in the return of President-elect Donald J. Trump. For now, Wall Streeters are looking past the risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The day after the presidential election, JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, knew it was time for a call he had hoped not to make.

articles.headline: Eric Trump Promises the ‘Most Pro-Crypto President’ in History
articles.snippet: Speaking at a Middle East conference, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s son said his family had embraced cryptocurrency because some banks stopped doing business with them after Jan. 6.
articles.abstract: Speaking at a Middle East conference, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s son said his family had embraced cryptocurrency because some banks stopped doing business with them after Jan. 6.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eric Trump flew across the world to headline a cryptocurrency conference in the United Arab Emirates this week and told thousands of enthusiastic attendees that he and his father, the U.S. president-elect, were effectively working in tandem to push crypto, a business sector the family is directly invested in.
articles.byline: By Ismaeel Naar, Eric Lipton, David Yaffe-Bellany and Tamir Kalifa

articles.headline: Panic at Pepperdine University in Malibu as Wildfires Threaten City
articles.snippet: No structures were damaged and no one was injured, but students spent a frantic night sheltering in place as thousands of nearby residents evacuated.
articles.abstract: No structures were damaged and no one was injured, but students spent a frantic night sheltering in place as thousands of nearby residents evacuated.
articles.lead_paragraph: The residence halls had lost power, and cell service was not working. Embers had sparked tiny flare-ups on the school grounds, setting palm trees ablaze. Helicopters were descending to extract water from a campus pond.
articles.byline: By Corina Knoll and Isabelle Taft

articles.headline: Judge Rejects Sale of Infowars to The Onion
articles.snippet: The Onion’s bid for the conspiracy website was supported by the families of victims of the Sandy Hook shooting and a nonprofit focused on ending gun violence.
articles.abstract: The Onion’s bid for the conspiracy website was supported by the families of victims of the Sandy Hook shooting and a nonprofit focused on ending gun violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: A judge late Tuesday night said he would not approve the sale of Infowars, the website founded by the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones, to the Chicago-based satirical publication The Onion, prolonging a messy tug of war between two high-profile suitors.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mullin and Elizabeth Williamson

articles.headline: Houthi Attacks Turn Back the Clock for Shipping as Costs Pile Up
articles.snippet: The transport route around the southern tip of Africa was once little used — but freighters are now forced to take it and are charging higher rates.
articles.abstract: The transport route around the southern tip of Africa was once little used — but freighters are now forced to take it and are charging higher rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before this year, Tobias Kammann, a German container ship captain, had only once sailed around the southern tip of Africa, and the lack of other vessels in the little-trafficked waters made him feel very much alone.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Britain Promised Clean Energy, but It Still Needs Oil
articles.snippet: The government wants to rapidly replace oil and natural gas with renewable energy projects, but offshore wind and other alternatives are still in their early stages.
articles.abstract: The government wants to rapidly replace oil and natural gas with renewable energy projects, but offshore wind and other alternatives are still in their early stages.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government of Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain finds itself in a quandary. It came to power promising to lead a clean energy boom that it said would revive a stagnant economy and protect consumers from energy price surges that were driving up inflation.

articles.headline: The Gold Rush at the Heart of a Civil War
articles.snippet: Famine and ethnic cleansing stalk Sudan. Yet the gold trade is booming, enriching generals and propelling the fight.
articles.abstract: Famine and ethnic cleansing stalk Sudan. Yet the gold trade is booming, enriching generals and propelling the fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: The luxury jet touched down in Juba, the capital of South Sudan, on a mission to collect hundreds of pounds of illicit gold.

articles.headline: Inflation Ticks Up, but Details Are Encouraging for the Fed
articles.snippet: Inflation sped up last month, but the details suggested cooling ahead. Next week, the Fed will make its final rate decision for 2024.
articles.abstract: Inflation sped up last month, but the details suggested cooling ahead. Next week, the Fed will make its final rate decision for 2024.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fresh inflation data released on Wednesday made clear that the Federal Reserve’s fight against rapid price increases was not over. Still, the details of the report probably gave central bank officials enough confidence to cut interest rates at their meeting next week.

articles.headline: Exxon Plans to Sell Electricity to Data Centers
articles.snippet: The country’s largest oil company is designing a natural gas power plant outfitted with carbon capture technology to meet the voracious power demand of technology companies.
articles.abstract: The country’s largest oil company is designing a natural gas power plant outfitted with carbon capture technology to meet the voracious power demand of technology companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Demand for electricity is rising so quickly in the United States that even Exxon Mobil, the country’s largest oil and gas company, is planning to get into the power business.

articles.headline: Albertsons Backs Out of Merger Deal and Sues Kroger After Court Rulings
articles.snippet: The supermarket chain had tried to join forces with Kroger, but judges sided with federal and state regulators who charged that the merger would reduce competition.
articles.abstract: The supermarket chain had tried to join forces with Kroger, but judges sided with federal and state regulators who charged that the merger would reduce competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: The grocery chain Albertsons said on Wednesday that it had backed out of its $25 billion merger with Kroger and sued its rival for failing to adequately push for regulatory approval, after both a federal and state judge blocked the deal on Tuesday.
